Calculate the integral of sin(x) cos(x)

To calculate the integral of sin(x) cos(x), we can use the substitution method. Let's substitute u = sin(x), then du/dx = cos(x) and dx = du/cos(x).

Now the integral becomes:

∫ sin(x) cos(x) dx = ∫ u du/cos(x) = ∫ u sec(x) du

We know that the integral of sec(x) is ln|sec(x) + tan(x)|, so we can substitute this back in:

∫ sin(x) cos(x) dx = ∫ u sec(x) du = ln|sec(x) + tan(x)| + C

Substituting back u = sin(x), we get:

∫ sin(x) cos(x) dx = ln|sec(x) + tan(x)| + C

Therefore, the integral of sin(x) cos(x) is ln|sec(x) + tan(x)| + C.
